Review Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution activities of metal chalcogenides and phosphides: Fundamentals, origins, and future strategies Xiaolin Hu a b c Ronghua Wang d ⁎ Wenlin Feng a Chaohe Xu b ⁎ Zidong Wei c ⁎ a School of Science, Chongqing University of Technology, Chongqing 400054, China School of Science Chongqing University of Technology Chongqing 400054 China School of Science, Chongqing University of Technology, Chongqing 400054, China b College of Aerospace Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China College of Aerospace Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China College of Aerospace Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China c School of Chemistry and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China School of Chemistry and Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China School of Chemistry and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China d College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphic abstract An overview summarized recent advances in transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) and phosphides (TMPs) OER electrocatalysts or pre-catalysts in terms of their chemical properties, catalytic performances evaluation and improvement strategies, and the future challenges for OER. The development of inexpensive and efficient electrocatalysts is key to commercializing energy-related electrocatalytic techniques such as water electrolyzers and metal-air batteries. In particular, novel oxygen evolution reaction (OER) pre-catalysts, such as transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) and phosphides (TMPs), have evolved in recent years from traditional stable OER electrocatalysts, which show superior OER electrocatalytic performance compared with transition metal oxides (TMOs) or (oxy)hydroxides (TMOHs). In this feature article, we summarize recent advances in the development of TMC- and TMP-based OER electrocatalysts, as well as approaches to improve the OER performance in terms of morphology, structure, composition, surface engineering, lattice-strained and in-situ transformation in the electrolysis process. In particular, the electrochemical stability of TMCs and TMPs in alkaline electrolytes and the evolution of morphology, structure and composition under OER conditions are discussed. In the last section, we discuss the challenges that need to be addressed in this specific area of research and the implications for further research. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Electrocatalysis Pre-catalysts Modulated strategies Structure-activity relationships Transition metal base compounds 1 Introduction With the massive consumption of fossil fuels and the growing demand for energy, there is an urgent need to find alternative energy sources and design efficient energy storage devices [1–5]. Metal-air batteries and electrochemical water splitting have been regarded as the most promising technologies to meet future energy requirements for various applications [6–9]. In both of these technologies, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is key to the cathodic reaction. However, OER usually has sluggish kinetics with complex oxidation processes and requires large overpotential (η) to deliver appreciable current [10–12]. Undoubtedly, the development of efficient electrocatalysts is critical to address these issues. At present, precious Ru- and Ir-based oxides with rutile structure are generally considered as state-of-the-art OER catalysts, where the Ru and Ir atoms are located at the center of the octahedral position, the oxygen atoms are located at the corners, and the octahedrons are connected to each other through shared corners. RuO2 and IrO2 are generally considered as the benchmark catalysts for OER due to their high electrocatalytic activities for OER in both acidic and alkaline solutions [13,14]. However, their practical applications are severely limited by their scarcity, high cost and constrained availability [15–17]. Therefore, in order to commercialize these promising energy-related technologies, it is imperative to design efficient, earth-abundant and inexpensive electrocatalysts with low overpotential. TMPs and TMCs have tunable intrinsic band gaps, valley degrees of freedom and other properties that hold great promise for applications in electrical, optical, spintronics and other device fields. Recently, nanosized transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) and phosphides (TMPs)-based materials have emerged as economical alternatives to precious metal-based water oxidation electrocatalysts [18,19], thanks to their unique physicochemical properties such as variable composition and structure, ideal electronic and magnetic properties [20,21], low-cost and earth-abundance. To be specific [22–24], TMPs and TMCs exhibit excellent catalytic activity and good stability to promote hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) due to their enhanced electronic conductivities. However, TMCs and TMPs are unstable during the OER process as predicted by the aqueous electrochemistry of metallic/non-metallic elements and solid-state chemistry [25–27]. Studies have reported that TMCs and TMPs are converted to metal oxides (TMOs) [28,29], (oxy)hydroxides (TMHOs) [30–32] or their heterostructures [33–35] during electrochemical anodic processes, and these as-formed high valence state TMOs/TMHOs are the real highly active OER catalytic species. In other words, TMCs and TMPs are not, strictly speaking, direct electrocatalysts of OER, but “pre-electrocatalysts” after electrochemical oxidation [36]. Nevertheless, most of the current studies still regard TMCs/TMPs as direct catalysts for electrochemical performance analysis or theoretical calculations [37–39]. Another aspect worth emphasizing is that TMOs and TMHOs formed in-situ at the interfaces have better OER performance than those synthesized by solution chemical reactions [40–42]. Generally speaking, OER performance usually depends on the number of active sites and the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst (intrinsic activity is the activity of the active sites) [43]. The exposure of the electrochemical active sites can be achieved by morphology engineering [44–48], single atomic site engineering [49–53], nanosize engineering [54–56], surface reconstruction [57–63], etc. To improve the intrinsic electrocatalytic activities towards OER, it requires researchers to fundamentally understand the electrochemical mechanism and accurately identify the active sites of different electrocatalysts. In recent decades, foreign elements doping, vacancies, strain engineering, and interface and/or phase engineering [64–67], have been proven to be reliable strategies for developing efficient OER catalysts; however, the underlying mechanism remains unclear. In this review, we examine the evolution of TMCs and TMPs from stable electrocatalysts to pre-electrocatalysts, and provide a detailed discussion of these non-oxides under OER conditions from the perspective of structure and composition changes. Because understanding the OER catalytic mechanism, the dynamic reconstruction of catalysts and the real catalytic active species of TMPs and TMCs is highly critical for rational design of high-performance OER electrocatalysts, the origins of OER activities of TMCs/TMPs and the in-situ phase evolution are firstly discussed in detail. Subsequently, after a deep understanding of the OER mechanisms, current strategies to improve their electrocatalytic performance are summarized. In the last section, we discuss the remaining challenges that need to be addressed and provide some potential areas of research. 2 Fundamentals and kinetics of OER 2.1 Fundamentals of OER OER is a pivotal step in water electrolyzers and rechargeable metal-air batteries (Fig. 1 ). Specifically, OER is a complex 4-electron process in which OH*, O*, and OOH* intermediates are formed sequentially with slow kinetics, and the mechanism has been reviewed in acidic or alkaline electrolytes by many research groups [65,68]. The most commonly believed mechanism is exhibited in reactions (1)–(5) or (6)–(10), as depicted in Fig. 2 (a). In acidic media [69,70]: (1) 2H2O → O2 + 4e− + 4H+ the overall reaction (2) 2H2O + * → OH* + H2O + H+ + e− (ΔG 1) (3) OH* + H2O → O* + H2O + H+ + e−(ΔG 2) (4) O* + H2O → OOH* + H+ + e−(ΔG 3) (5) OOH* → O2 + H+ + e−(ΔG 4) In alkaline media [71]: (6) 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + e− the overall reaction (7) 4OH− → OH* + 3OH− + e−(ΔG 5) (8) OH* + 3OH−→ O* + 2OH− + H2O + e−(ΔG 6) (9) O* + 2OH− + H2O → OOH* + OH− + H2O + e−(ΔG 7) (10) OOH* + OH− + H2O → O2 + H2O + e−(ΔG 8) The theoretical overpotential is defined as, (11) η OER = Max [ Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 , o r Δ G 5 , Δ G 6 , Δ G 7 , Δ G 8 ] / e - 1.23 V where, * is the active site, OH*, O* and OOH* represent the intermediates absorbing on *, ΔG is the change of Gibbs free energy, and η is the overpotential. The theoretical potential of water splitting is 1.23 V relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). For example, Fan et al. captured the stepwise oxidative evolution of the amorphous electrocatalyst CoS x to crystalline CoOOH by in situ techniques in alkaline OER. The irreversible conversion of CoS x to crystalline CoOOH during OER measurements was initiated at the electrocatalyst surface via a Co(OH)2 intermediate, where CoOOH was identified as the true active species. The CoS x required an overpotential of 396 mV to reach a catalytic current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is almost the same as that of commercial RuO2 (398 mV) [72]. The main mechanism followed is the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) mechanism, but the detailed transformation process and catalytic mechanism have not been clearly revealed. Usually, the widely recognized OER mechanism is the above-mentioned AEM, which involves a four-electron–proton synergistic transfer process at the transition metal cation site to produce O2. In recent years, a new lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) has been proposed (Fig. 2c) based on the redox process of the lattice oxygen anion and the reversible formation of oxygen vacancies (VO) on the surface of transition metal oxides, as shown in Eqs. (12)–(15). It eliminates the proton-electron co-transfer process in the conventional AEM. The ()† in the following equation represents the calculation by placing the adsorbates in the same supercell [73]. (12) *OH → (VO + *OO)† + H+ + e− (13) (VO + *OO)† + H2O → O2 + (VO + *OH)† + H+ + e− (14) (VO + *OH)† + H2O → (*HO-site + *OH)† + H+ + e− (15) (*HO-site + *OH)† → *OH + H+ + e− All of these complex multistage reactions require robust and efficient electrocatalysts to accelerate the kinetics because it is a thermodynamically uphill reaction. In addition, the actual catalytic potential is higher than 1.23 V due to the non-ideal process in the experiment (charge transfer resistance, contact resistance between catalyst and trap, solution resistance, etc.) and the less-than-ideal catalytic active sites which introduce high energy barriers. Higher overpotential during OER greatly decreases the energy efficiency of fuel cells, metal air batteries and water splitting, further limiting their large-scale commercial applications. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are important for evaluating and predicting electrocatalytic activities, revealing possible reaction pathways, and disclosing the underlying mechanism. The theoretical overpotential can be calculated by Eq. (11). Taking the spinel [Mn]T[Al0.5Mn1.5]OO4 as an example, as shown in Fig. 2(b), ideally, all reactions have zero free energy at the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V (black line). In fact, the reaction does not satisfy the ideal thermodynamic equilibrium at practical conditions. The results show that the adsorption energy for the generation of O* and HOO* is significantly insufficient with a calculated overpotential of 1.474 V (red line). Therefore, understanding the basic principle of OER and combining with theoretical simulation to find the most suitable materials to adsorb the intermediates, and finally verifying by electrochemical experiments, is an effective way to develop efficient OER catalytic materials. 2.2 Electrocatalytic kinetics One of the core tasks for electrocatalysis is the selection of appropriate catalytic materials, which can accelerate the reaction or change the reaction path during electrocatalytic processes. Additionally, electrochemical reactions involve charge transfer and chemical state change, as shown in the reaction of (10), which can be evaluated by several parameters, such as overpotential (η), exchange current density (i 0), Tafel slope (b), electrochemical surface area (ECSA) and stability. (16) Oxi. + ne− → Red. If there is no catalyst in the system, the reactant must gain energy Ea and then change to the activated state A* so as to cross the energy barrier and become the final product. Similarly, for the reverse reaction, the product only obtains the energy Ea' to cross the energy barrier to become A'* (Fig. 3 ). However, if an appropriate electrocatalyst is introduced into the reaction, it can successfully reduce the energy barrier and thus accelerate the reaction. In addition, some reactions with low energy barriers are thermodynamically easy but kinetically difficult to perform. In these cases, electrocatalysts can lower the energy barrier by creating intermediate states. Therefore, the development of efficient catalysts has always been the focus of the chemical industry. 2.3 Electrochemical cell and methods 2.3.1 Electrochemical cell Generally, a three-electrode electrochemical electrolytic cell consisting of a reference electrode (RE, generally Ag|AgCl, Hg|HgO or saturated glycerol electrodes), a working electrode (WE), and a counter electrode (CE, usually carbon rods or Pt wire), is used to record the catalytic performance, as shown in Fig. 4 . The choice of RE is described here. For alkaline systems, we can use Hg|HgO electrode with a Teflon and alkaline stabilized frit (note that mercury is toxic and care should be taken to avoid damaging the frit). Because the filling solution in the RE is matched to the electrolyte solution in the cell, which eliminates potential or cross contamination, we can keep a set of RE for use under the cleanest, iron-free electrolyte conditions. Saturated calomel electrodes (SCE) are generally used as reference electrodes under acidic conditions, while SCE and Ag|AgCl RE electrodes are more suitable for near-neutral pH studies, since they do not have alkaline stability. Theoretically, RE electrodes, are ideally non-polarizing electrodes, i.e., the electrode potential does not change with current. In practice, the RE itself is affected to a greater or lesser extent as the electrochemical test temperature and pH change. Calibration of the RE is necessary, especially in electrocatalytic reactions that compare overpotential, and calculations using a well-calibrated RE will yield data that are closer to the real thing. Each RE should be calibrated using a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) before first use and tested periodically for drift [75]. For electrolytes, both acidic and alkaline electrolytes can be used, depending on catalytic materials. The acidic electrolytes are generally 1.0 M H2SO4 or 0.1 M HClO4 solutions; the alkaline electrolytes are 0.1 or 1.0 M KOH aqueous solutions. The electrolytes need to be saturated with oxygen for a period of time before testing to increase the stability of the RE and to fix the reversible oxygen potential [75]. For most of transition metal based catalytic materials, KOH solution is the preferred electrolyte owing to high solubility and ionic conductivity, while NaOH can also be used as an alternative. Previous studies have demonstrated that the dissolved ions greatly affect the OER catalytic performance. Hunter et al. reported that the dissolved carbonates can enhance the catalytic activity of Ni(Fe)O x H y films in KOH solution [76]. Markovic et al. also found that the existence of a dynamic Fe ion dissolution-deposition equilibrium between electrolyte and electrocatalyst can greatly promote the water oxidation reaction. The reason is that the dynamic Fe sites work as the active sites with high efficiency. Inspired by these studies, the design of new electrocatalytic materials should comprehensively consider the dynamic stability of the active sites at the solid/liquid interfaces [77]. The dissolved NO3 − may also significantly lower the OER overpotential. Recently, an unprecedented low OER overpotential of 32 mV was reported for a NiS x /C3N4 material by Zahran et al. The experiments demonstrate that the electrolyte does not contain NO3 −, indicating that it is the NiS x /C3N4 material itself rather than NO3 − that contributes to the OER reaction [78]. In summary, the dissolved oxygen, the diffusion coefficient and the dissolved ions in the electrolyte are very important for OER and need to be considered during electrochemical testing. 2.3.2 Electrochemical methods Electrocatalytic activity testing . In order to evaluate the electrocatalytic activities, cyclic voltammetry (CV), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and Tafel plots are usually carried out and recorded. Before data recording, tens of CV cycles should be performed first to ensure a clean electrode surface and stable/accurate curves. For the LSV method, an 80% to 100% iR-compensation (i and R represent current and resistance, respectively) will be adopted for the working electrode, considering the resistances of electrolytes and interfaces. Thus, this value should be specified for data analysis. The presence of ionic currents between the WE and the RE causes a drop in the potential value, and the usual uncompensated resistance (R 0) can be obtained using the following equation [79] (17) R 0 = l σ A where, σ is the conductivity of the electrolyte solution, A is the effective area of WE, and l represents the distance between WE and RE. The corrected voltage value (E c) can be obtained by the following equation (18) E c = E m - i R 0 Stability testing . Stability is generally evaluated by CV, Chronopotentiometry and Chronoamperometry, which can only be measured at the same current or the same voltage. In contrast, the multi-step Chronoamperometry is a method by which the voltage is controlled and the change in current flowing through the electrode as a function of time is measured simultaneously at different potential step segments. This allows the stability of the electrocatalyst to be measured simultaneously at different potentials. It is particularly important to note that catalyst instability is easily demonstrated by Chronopotentiometry and Chronoamperometry, but the proof of Chronopotentiometry and Chronoamperometry alone is not sufficient to prove that the catalyst is stable. It is desirable to systematically characterize the catalyst before and after OER via techniques such as in-situ or ex-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), Raman, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), etc. 2.4 Critical parameters The electrochemical reaction refers to a complex charge transferring process occurred at the electrode/electrolyte interface, as shown in reaction (10). In order to gain an in-depth understanding of the reaction and regulate the catalytic activity and rate, a number of basic parameters are generally employed to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance, such as overpotential (η), exchange current density (i 0), exchange current (j 0), Tafel slope (b), electrochemically active surface area (ECSA), turnover frequency (TOF) and stability. 2.4.1 Overpotential (η) Owing to the sluggish kinetics, it requires a potential larger than the equilibrium value of 1.23 V (vs. RHE) to trigger OER, and this difference is named as overpotential (η). Overpotentials are generally associated with activation overpotentials, uncompensated resistance and differential concentration polarization. These overpotentials, especially the activation overpotential, are directly related to the intrinsic activities of electrocatalysts [80,81]. Thus, overpotential is a key descriptor for evaluating the OER performance. Overpotential is usually calculated from LSV curves and recorded at a low scan rate to eliminate the influence of non-Faraday currents as much as possible. The potential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 is usually chosen as the benchmark (recorded as j 10), which corresponds to 10% of the solar conversion efficiency. The smaller this value is, the better the catalytic activity [82–84]. However, for some catalytic materials, there is a strong reduction peak which covers up j 10. In these cases, a large current density such as 20, 50 or 100 mA cm−2 can be used as the benchmark current density. It should be noted that j 10 and η 10 are not an absolute parameter to exhibit the intrinsic activity. The reason is that these two values are also related to catalyst loading. The larger the catalyst loading, the lower the j 10 and η 10. Therefore, we recommend to normalize j and η to both the mass loading and geometric area, or the real surface area of the loaded electrocatalysts. 2.4.2 Exchange current density (i 0) and Tafel slope (b) The exchange current density (i 0) responds to the intrinsic efficiency of electron transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface [85]. The higher the exchange current density, the higher the catalytic activity. The exchange current is equal to the current at zero overpotential (marked as j 0). The exchange current density can be expressed by the following equation (19) i 0 = j 0 A where A is the effective area. The relationship between current density (j) and η in OER can be described by the Butler-Volmer equation. When the anodic overpotential is large enough, the formula is as follows (20) j = j 0 α a n F η RT where R is the universal gas constant, T is the thermodynamic temperature, α a is the transfer coefficient of anodic reaction, n is the number of transferred electrons and F is the Faraday’s constant. Tafel slope (b) is an important descriptor of the kinetic parameters, revealing the relationship between the stable-state current density and overpotential. Generally, the smaller the Tafel slope, the faster the charge transfer rate and the better the kinetic performance. The b equation is as follows [85] (21) log j = l o g j 0 + η b (22) b = 2.303 R T anF Logically, from the b equation, it can be seen that b is inversely proportional to the current and positively proportional to η in a suitable range. Furthermore, when the current density is constant, the lower the η, the smaller the value of b and the higher the kinetic performance of the catalyst. In addition, b is also an important parameter to understand the reaction mechanism, especially to elucidate the rate determining steps. Different values of b in different intervals imply different rate-determining steps, and a smaller b indicates that the rate-determining step is at the end of the multi-electron transfer reaction, which signifies that the catalyst is a good electrocatalyst [86,87]. 2.4.3 Electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) In the case of conventional electrodes, ECSA is considered to be the effective geometric area wetted by electrolyte. However, for electrodes composed of nanomaterials with a large comparative area and a relatively larger number of exposed active sites, ECSA cannot simply be considered as the effective geometric area [88]. Usually, it can be estimated based on the electrochemical double layer capacitance. There are two ways to calculate ECSA. The first one is to measure the non-Faradaic capacitive current associated with the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) from the CV curves tested in a potential range without redox process. The relationship between the C dl and the scan rate (v, mV s−1) is shown as follows (23) i c = v C d l where, ic is the charging current (mA cm−2). The other way to calculate ESCA is to detect the frequency-dependent impedance of the system from electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) [89]. 2.4.4 Turnover frequency (TOF) Turnover frequency (TOF), which is the number of conversions of a single active site per unit time, can be used to reveal the intrinsic activity of each active site of electrocatalysts, that is, the number of moles of O2 precipitated per unit catalytic active sites. The formula for TOF is shown as follows (24) TOF = J N A A n F Γ where, г represents the surface concentration, F is the Faradaic efficiency (F = 96485.3 s A mol−1), n is the number of electrons transferred from the reaction, A is the effective geometric area of the electrode, J is the current at a given overpotential, and NA is the Avogadro constant (NA = 6.02 × 1023). 2.4.5 Stability Generally, thermodynamics determines whether a reaction can occur, while kinetics determines how fast the reaction proceeds. Stability is another critical parameter for OER, which accounts for the span life of the electrocatalysts as well as the energy systems. CV, chronoamperometry, and chronopotentiometry are usually used to evaluate the electrocatalytic stability of electrocatalysts. Long-term CV cycles are generally performed to evaluate the stability by comparing η, b and TOF before and after cycles. The smaller the deviation, the better the stability. By using potentionstatic and galvanostatic tests, the time period is generally required to last at least 12 h. The current decrease in a fixed current density or the potential increase at a fixed current density (usually in 10 mA cm−2) reflects the stability of the catalyst. The smaller the change in current density or overpotential, the better the stability. 3 Origins of the OER catalytic activity Thanks to their abundant reserves, uniquely charged properties and high catalytic activities [90,91], TMPs and TMCs have attracted intensive attention as electrocatalytic materials in recent decades. However, the catalytic performance is limited by their non-ideal electronic conductivities and insufficient active sites. To date, a series of methods have been proposed to improve the electrocatalytic activity, lower the overpotential and further enhance the energy efficiency of energy systems, such as heteroatom doping [92], introduction of polymetallic sites [93–95], compounding with highly conductive materials [96,97], stress engineering, heterostructure engineering [98,99], etc. However, despite these achievements, the electrocatalytic mechanisms, especially the origins of the catalytic activity, are still under debate. In recent years, TMPs and TMCs have emerged as promising candidates for efficient electrocatalysis, capable of greater electrical conductivity than transition metal oxides (TMOs), some of which are even metallicity. However, most TMPs and TMCs exhibit electrochemical instability under OER conditions, based on predictions for the aqueous chemistry of metals and the solid chemistry of non-metals. Many studies have reported that TMPs and TMCs would undergo in situ electrochemical conversion under anodic oxidation conditions and be irreversibly converted into transition metal (oxygen) hydroxides (TMOs), which are the true catalytically active substances in OER. In this sense, TMCs and TMPs are technically pre-catalysts rather than catalysts. For example, there are many reports claiming that TMPs and TMCs are sufficiently stable during OER to act as true electrocatalytic active species [100,101], while some recent studies show that TMPs and TMCs are unstable and undergo an oxidation process [26,102,103], indicating they are not the real electrocatalysts. After oxidation, an oxide or hydroxide layer is in-situ formed on the surface of TMPs and TMCs, or completely converted to oxides or hydroxides via phase reconstruction during the OER process. Undoubtedly, the as-formed oxidizing layers are the actual electrocatalytic species. In this section, we will give a detailed summary to discuss the origins of the OER activities of TMPs and TMCs. 3.1 TMCs and TMPs as electrocatalytic active materials 3.1.1 TMCs as electrocatalysts TMCs, such as TC, TC2, Ni3C2, T3C4, and T9C8 (T = Fe, Co, Ni; CS, Se, Te) [104–109], are emerging as attractive electrocatalysts because of their chemical resistance against acid/alkaline electrolytes (no corrosion) and intrinsic electronic conductivities (fast charge transfer capability) [110]. Generally, with the exception of T9C8, T3C2 and T3C4, TMCs can be synthesized by sulfurization or selenization to form a pyrite/topaz crystal structure, in which the metal atoms are located in the center sites of the S/Se octahedrons. In TC2, the [TC6] octahedron is connected to the atomic bond [C2]2− by CC, resulting in the divalent oxidation states of Co and Ni instead of + 4. These compounds generally exhibit robust electrochemical performance with an overpotential in the range of 200 to 300 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 [111–114]. Accordingly, Chen et al. [115] synthesized NiS on a stainless-steel mesh support via a one-pot hydrothermal method. The catalysts show a low overpotential of 297 mV at a current density of 11 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of only 47 mV dec−1, demonstrating more competitive performance at very high current densities. Cai et al. [116] synthesized amorphous cobalt sulfide porous nanotubes (A-CoS4.6O0.6PNCs) with an overpotential of 290 mV and a Tafel slope of around 67 mV dec−1. As shown in Fig. 5 , Feng and coworkers [117] found that Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays with high index facet exposure have high electro-catalytic OER performance. The different facets of Ni3S2 nanosheet array exhibit different OER electrochemical activities in electrochemical measurements. The free energy diagrams of OER on ( 2 ¯ 10) and (001) surfaces by DFT calculation show that OER on the (10) 2 ¯ surfaces is highly active compared to that of the (001) surfaces. When bias (black line) is applied, the overpotential required for the ( 2 ¯ 10) and (001) surfaces is 580 and 700 mV, respectively, indicating that the (10) 2 ¯ surface exhibits an enhanced catalytic activity for OER. Furthermore, Ni3S2 exhibits significant catalytic stability over 200 h. Although this work has been systematically and ingeniously conceived, it does not clarify the details in terms of stability. The excellent catalytic stability of the system only indicates that the catalytic reaction is stable, not that the catalyst itself is stable. In addition to metallic sulfides, some researchers have reported that metallic selenides are promising candidates for OER in terms of activity and stability. A near-unity occupancy of the eg orbital in surface metal cations always predicts high intrinsic OER activity. Cubic CoSe2 in the form of t 2 g 6 e g 1 configuration, with Co 3d electrons close to the optimal eg filling, should be a promising candidate for OER catalysts. For instance, Zhang et al. [118] obtained CoSe2 which exhibits a low overpotential of 284 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 46.3 mV dec−1, with good stability over 20 h. Likewise, CoSe2 microspheres were also synthesized with a low overpotential of 330 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 79 mV dec−1, displaying no obvious decay after 1000 cyclic voltammetry cycles [119]. Despite the stable performance, the catalyst undergoes chemical reconstitution under alkaline and strong oxidizing conditions. Chen and coworkers [120] reported the preparation of CoNiSe2/NF that delivers OER with an overpotential of as low as 307 mV at the current density of 100 mA cm−2 with an extremely high stability. Fang et al. [121] designed NiCo2Se4-based holey nanosheets with a low applied external potential of 1.68 V at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for high-performing overall water splitting. In summary, TMCs seem to be able to effectively catalyze the formation of O2 in the process of water oxidation with good stability. However, we believe that the system may only be stable in terms of performance and that the chemical stability of the catalyst is open to debate. The study of the chemical structure and properties of TMCs provides a basis for the investigation of its structure-composition-property relationship. 3.1.2 TMPs as electrocatalysts Transition metal phosphides (TMPs), especially Ni, Co and Fe-based phosphides as non-noble metal compounds, have attracted more and more attention as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for water oxidation [122–127], benefitting from their unique physicochemical properties such as ideal electron and magnetic properties, and variable compositions and structures [20]. TMPs are generally obtained by phosphine reactions, which are very complex because different compositions and stoichiometric ratios can produce different structures. Taken the nickel phosphide as an example, there are more than nine types of binary nickel phosphide with different stoichiometric ratios [66]. A slight change in the stoichiometric ratio of metal to phosphorus results in a significant change in its structural and physicochemical properties. Zeng et al. [128] constructed Ni2P/Ni3S2 heteronanoflake arrays with an extremely low overpotential of 210 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for OER in 1.0 M KOH, and a reasonably stable OER activity was observed for 24 h. Similar to nickel phosphide, extensive studies have been carried out on metal phosphorous compounds such as Co2N, Co3N, Co4N, Ni3N, TP and T2P (T = Fe, Co and Ni) and composite metal phosphides due to their good conductivity. For instance, Cui et al. performed electrochemical tuning of lithium transition-metal phosphates as efficient water oxidation catalysts [129]. The overpotential is only 270 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and no degradation is observed over 24 h in 0.1 M KOH. The abundant metal bond and metal phosphorus bond can endow TMPs with better electron conductivity, thermal stability and chemical stability compared with the phosphorus bond. Liang et al. [23] successfully designed NiPS3/Ni2P heterostructures thanks to good lattice matching and element similarity, which display high OER activity in 1.0 M KOH, and the stability is maintained at more than 76% at the current density of 20 mA cm−2 after 12 h (Fig. 6 a–c). Qiu et al. [130] fabricated Ni-Co bimetal phosphide nanocages, which deliver a remarkable OER catalytic activity at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η = 300 mV) and stay stable for at least 10 h. Guo et al. [131] developed Co2P-CoN core–shell nanoparticles with a high gravimetric energy density of 844.5 W h kg−1 for Zn-air batteries and excellent stability (no activity decay after CV scanning for 5000 cycles). Lin et al. [39] constructed multi-dimensional core/shell Ni/NiCoP nano-heterojunction with an overpotential of 260 mV at the current density of 20 mA cm−2, which are stable for more than 43 h. Here, heterogeneous structures with abundant phase boundaries facilitate the application of surface-mediated electrochemistry, while the tuning structure and electronic state of the electrocatalysts are essential to achieve highly efficient water oxidation. Gawande et al. [132] presented the Ag@Co x P core–shell heterojunction structure and experimentally confirmed the migration of electron density from Co to Ag (Fig. 6d). The interaction enhances the catalytic activity of Ag@Co x P, which is 8 times higher than that of Co2P with an overpotential of 310 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and the catalytic reaction is stable for 20 h at an overpotential of 274 mV (Fig. 6e). The Ag core enhances the catalytic activity of Co x P by modulating its electronic structure, while the nature of the electronic structure determines the electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of the catalyst can be improved from the perspective of the electronic structure of the material, so that structures with high catalytic activities can be designed. When the chemical structure and properties are subsequently investigated, it will be of great interest to reveal the conformational relationships of TMPs. The above-mentioned cases are good indications of the high electrocatalytic activity of TMPs, which is mainly attributed to their unique physicochemical properties, tunable electronic structures, tunable compositions and rich active sites. With continuous efforts, TMPs have been vigorously developed, which exhibit excellent OER activity and stability in alkaline electrolytes. It is worth noting that the widely accepted conclusion that TMP is stable during alkaline OER is mainly based on chronoamperometry or chronopotentiometry measurements. However, many studies have reported that TMP is thermodynamically less stable at oxidation overpotentials under alkaline conditions, and that the contained P components may dissolve into the electrolyte. Thus, the real active catalyst may not be TMP but the product after oxidation. It is worth mentioning that all these above studies have designed perfect TMC and TMP structures with excellent OER electrochemical properties. Stability measurements have shown that the OERs are stable. However, some researchers speculate that these TMCs and TMPs may not be stable OER catalysts, but only function as pre-electrocatalysts [26,64,133]. The TMCs and TMPs were subsequently characterized after the stability measurements, and the results show that some of the catalysts underwent surface oxidation or even bulk oxidation, indicating that the TMCs and TMPs are not the real catalysts but pre-catalysts in the OER process. The in-situ oxidation process not only improves the electrochemical performance, but also increases the resistance to acid and alkali electrolytes, thus increasing the stability of the catalyst. 3.2 Interfacial oxidizing layers as OER catalytic materials Recently, more and more research work on electrocatalytic oxygen evolution has appeared in the literatures, reporting that TMPs and TMCs can also be used as efficient and stable catalysts for oxygen evolution and have shown good catalytic results. However, an extremely important and often overlooked issue is that these compounds are not thermodynamically stable under strong oxidative electrochemical environments. There is now sufficient experimental evidence to show that these compounds are highly susceptible to oxidation and will be converted to the corresponding oxides or hydroxides while testing. Professor Song Jin of the University of Wisconsin-Madison recently published an editorial in ACS Energy Letters [26], stating that TMCs and TMPs are not necessarily electrocatalytic oxygen precipitating materials in the usual sense. The so-called “efficient and stable” catalytic performance of these materials during testing is most likely due to the rapid completion of the oxidation process on the surface of the material at the start of the electrochemical reaction and the conversion to the corresponding oxides or hydroxides, which are the true active substances in the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction. This raises a new scientific question, how to exactly understand the nature of these oxygen evolution catalysts? Are they truly electrocatalytic oxygen evolution materials? In response to these questions and debates, we examined the evolution of TMCs and TMPs from stable electrocatalysts to pre-electrocatalysts in this review, and provide a detailed discussion of these non-oxides under OER conditions from the perspective of structure and composition changes, in the hope of providing some thinking and reference for the subsequent research. The degree of oxidation is closely related to the electrocatalytic performance, and some catalysts are less active than the pre-catalyst after several hundred CVs. This is related to the degree of activation of the pre-catalyst. During the activation or CV test of the pre-catalyst, the Faraday capacitance of the first CV is generally the smallest, indicating that the activity of the pre-catalyst is the lowest. With subsequent CV cycling tests, the increase in Faraday capacitance in the CV curves suggests that the activity of the pre-catalyst gradually increases during the reconstruction. However, continuous CV activation may lead to a decrease in the pre-catalyst activity. Therefore, the thickness of the surface oxide layer also affects the OER catalytic activity. It has been experimentally demonstrated that the formation of heterojunctions by partial sulphation can accelerate the catalytic reactions [134]. Surface oxidation of TMC and TMP compounds can protect them from electrolyte corrosion, or lead to the formation of a heterojunction structure that improves the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The interface between the two components can change the bonding electron energy level, thus enhancing the reactivity and selectivity of the catalyst. The chemistry in the OER is very complicated, involving irreversible surface oxidations of TMCs/TMPs and conversion to corresponding TMOs/TMOHs. These in-situ changes have been widely observed and applied in the design of more active catalysts with superior performance. Our previous work [135] has demonstrated that the synergistic interaction of OH and S ligands on the NiCo2(SOH) x surface can subtly modulate the electronic structure of the metal active center and its chemical environment, thus enabling enhanced synergistic catalysis. The optimal binding energies of the OER intermediates (*OH, *O and *OOH) and the enhanced binding energies between the metal and the anionic ligands lead to excellent intrinsically enhanced stability and OER activity, respectively. Han et al. [136] synthesized a NiSe/CFs catalyst with an overpotential of 318 mV at the current density of 50 mA cm−2 and 120 h stability for OER at the current density of 20 mA cm−2. It is worth noting that the newly generated NiOOH may be the true active site during the OER trials. Ryu et al. [137] reported that CoP nanoparticles can achieve significant OER efficiencies by activating CoP to form CoO(OH), which exhibit comparable activities to the precious iridium catalysts. A more significant feature is the long-term stability, which is superior to iridium and traditional cobalt-oxygen-based materials. Similar surface oxidation was also found in 1D nanostructured Co2P, resulting in products with higher activities compared with pure cobalt oxides [138]. Yan et al. [139] constructed a NiS/Ni coupled interface and the overpotential is only 301 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope is 46 mV dec−1. The construction of the NiS/Ni interface is conducive to the surface oxidation of Ni with a higher oxidation state, which facilitates the evolution of oxygen. You et al. [140] reported Ni2P/Ni/NF with a small overpotential of 200 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is attributed to the surface oxidation of the catalyst to nickel oxide/hydroxide/hydroxide (mainly NiO). Zhou et al. [141] synthesized Fe(PO3)2/Ni2P delivering an overpotential below 300 mV at ultra-high oxidative current densities above 500 mA cm−2, which may be associated with the in-situ generated FeOOH and Ni-Fe oxide/hydroxide catalysts at the surface (Fig. 7 a–f). Sun et al. [142] fabricated Fe-doped Ni2P nanoparticles embedded in carbon nanotubes. Characterization and DFT calculations of these nanoparticles revealed that they are in-situ transformed into Fe/P doped γ-NiOOH during OER, which act as the actual OER active sites (Fig. 7g–i). Liu and coworkers [143] synthesized hollow Fe-Co-P alloy nanostructures with a low overpotential of 252 mV at a specific current density of 10 mA cm−2, showing good OER electrochemical properties that are three orders of magnitude higher than those of the nanostructures prepared with the most advanced Fe-Co oxide catalysts. This is due to the formation of FeOOH in a high state on the alloy surface, which induces Co into a lower state. Such a difference in the valence state leads to the simultaneous enhancement of the activity and stability of the OER catalyst. Therefore, during the OER process, the electrocatalyst surface sites have dynamic characteristics that can trigger the occurrence of remodeling. By connecting the electrocatalyst surface with the active sites involved in the reaction, the surface reconstruction can regulate the adsorption, activation and desorption behaviors of the electrocatalyst, optimize the electronic structure, accelerate the charge transfer, and thus affect the OER performance. TMPs and TMCs may undergo morphological and structural changes under alkaline OER conditions. Indeed, many researchers have reported catalysts that can form TMP/TMO or TMP/TMHO heterostructures during OER tests. Hu et al. found for the first time that Ni2P is surface oxidized under OER catalytic conditions, forming a core-shell (Ni2P/NiO x ) heterostructure in-situ to facilitate the catalytic OER [144]. The HRTEM analysis of the catalyst and the elemental mapping are presented, which indicates the presence of a shell or cover composed of nickel oxide/hydroxide. Following this finding, a Ni2P/Fe2P interface was constructed [145], which can be in-situ oxidized and transformed to the Ni2P(O)/Fe2P(O) interface to improve OER efficiency. Liang et al. [146] first designed metallic NiFeP and further constructed amorphous NiFe hydroxide/NiFeP heterostructures using the PH3 plasma treatment, in which the strong electronic interactions significantly enhance the OER performance. Remarkably, the as-synthesized a-NiFe-OH/NiFeP/NF only requires an overpotential of 258 mV to achieve the current density of 300 mA cm−2 in alkaline media at the small Tafel slope of 39 mV dec–1. The overpotential of CoMnP nanoparticles as a water oxidation electrocatalyst is 0.33 V with a Faraday efficiency of 96%. However, such catalysts are dynamic. For example, Brock et al. [147] found that the activity of CoMnP decreases as the number of CV activations increases, which may be due to the fact that P is etched into the electrolyte solution as revealed by the disappearance of the low-energy P2p3/2 peak at 129.7 eV, suggesting the formation of oxides on the catalyst surface. Therefore, many researchers have tried to demonstrate that TMPs are efficient catalysts for water oxidation because of the special electronic structure, high electronegativity and excellent electrical conductivity of P. However, after a long period of cycling, the surface is oxidized, which may lead to a decrease in the electrochemical performance. Therefore, the rational use of heteroatomic P elements is particularly important. Currently, phosphate buffer can be introduced to inhibit P etching, but its stabilization effect has yet to be evaluated, and its compositional effect needs to be investigated. Although most researchers believe that TMPs are efficient catalysts, oxidation may occur on the surface. For example, Ni1.25Ru0.75P electrocatalysts have been developed, which can promote partial oxidation of Ni due to Ru’s electron activation effect on Ni, thus reducing the kinetic potential barrier of OER. However, using the most active Ni1.25Ru0.75P as the catalyst to evaluate its stability, the overpotential increases from 0.34 to 0.37 V after 300 cycles, and the NiII/NiIII/IV oxidation peaks shift to higher potentials as the number of cycles increase [148]. These results demonstrate that TMPs act as a dynamic catalyst and undergo surface oxidation. To be precise, this phenomenon may be attributed to the low intrinsic activity of the reconstructed (oxy)hydroxide rather than the original pre-catalyst after a long period of cycling. Therefore, it is a challenge to suppress the reconstruction of the pre-catalyst and maintain its original high activity in this case. In fact, because the conversion of the pre-catalyst to reconstituted species occurs during the electrochemical process, it is difficult to assess the true activity of the pre-catalyst. Therefore, there is still a long way to explore the intrinsic activity of pre-catalysts and elucidate the catalytic reaction mechanism. There are also indications that the surface oxidation of TMCs and TMPs to form heterogeneous structures is beneficial to OER reactions, because these structures can not only effectively regulate the physical and electronic structure of each component, but also construct hybrid materials with strong interface coupling (van der Waals Heterostructures). For instance, Sun et al. have recently reported a NiSe/NF nanowire with an overpotential of 270 mV at the current density of 20 mA cm−2 in alkaline solution, and the as-formed NiOOH species at the NiSe surface serve as the actual catalytic sites [149]. Moreover, Hu et al. found that NiSe is entirely converted into nickel hydroxide under OER conditions, and the generated metal oxides are responsible for the electrocatalytic activity [102]. Zhang et al. [150] developed a porous Fe-Co-P nano-box as the pre-catalyst for alkaline OER, which exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity with a small overpotential of 269 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) analyses and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the structural advantage between Fe and Co atoms through the P/O bridges and the effective intramolecular electron coupling greatly enhance the electrocatalytic activity. Chen et al. [151] revealed that the Ni2P/NiOOH core-shell structure is formed after phase reconstruction on the surface of the Ni2P pre-catalyst. After reconstructing the heterojunctions, the high-valent metal species formed on the surface can promote the electrostatic adsorption of OH– and the retained pre-catalyst nuclei can enhance the electron transfer during the catalytic process. The oxides/hydroxides or oxyhydroxides formed on the surface accelerate the evolution kinetics of oxygen, thus significantly improving the catalytic performance. Apparently, modulating the structure of the material by a variety of chemical methods can induce reconfigurations and thus enhance the electrochemical performance. For example, the vacancies induced by doping trigger surface reconfiguration of the pre-catalyst, and the formation of moderate M−O species on the surface induces the redistribution of surface electronic states, which can optimize the adsorption of OH* and OOH* intermediates on metal oxyhydroxides. Under these conditions, MoS2 exhibits OER activities with an overpotential of only 323 mV at the current density of 30 mA cm−2, although it is generally considered as an active electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reactions [152]. All the studies mentioned above have demonstrated that TMPs and TMCs are pre-catalysts under water oxidation reaction conditions. Different pre-catalysts exhibit different effects in the OER process, which deserves a systematic study by researchers. Strategies that make full use of surface reconstruction to optimize reaction paths and lower energy barriers are also worth considering. To sum up, TMP and TMC pre-catalysts undergo reconstruction due to their inherent instability under oxidation conditions. Due to the limited extent of reconstruction, oxides/hydroxides or oxyhydroxides are usually generated on the surface of the pre-catalyst, leading to the formation of a pre-catalyst/reconstructed layer core–shell heterojunction structure, in which the reconstructed layer acts as the active catalytic component while the pristine pre-catalyst achieves effective electron transfer from the native catalyst. This can greatly promote the electrocatalytic activity and cycling stability. However, if continued under oxidation conditions, a complete reconstruction of the pre-catalyst will occur. Although some studies have reported that continuous oxidation leads to reduced catalytic activity, the exact relationship between the degree of pre-catalyst reconstruction and OER activity is still unclear and needs to be investigated systematically. 3.3 Bulk oxidation to achieve high OER activities In addition to surface oxidation, the phase of TMCs and TMPs may undergo a complete transformation if surface oxidation persists and changes to bulk oxidation. The reconstructed species may exhibit similar properties to the surface reconstructed species, or new materials may be synthesized through such complete reconstructions. In general, complete reconstruction results in the following changes: reduced crystallinity or conversion to amorphous [153–155], interconnected porous structures of ultrasmall nano catalytic units generated by the dissolution of components into the electrolyte [77,103,156], species that can be tentatively determined with maximum stability and activity utilization [157–161], complete reconstruction accompanied by doping, etc [142,162]. For example, the transformation of CoS x to CoOOH via Co(OH)2 intermediates (CoS x → Co(OH)2 → CoOOH) has been revealed using in situ and ex situ techniques [72], during which their morphology changes from the original rhombic dodecahedral particles to nanosheets (Fig. 8 a and b), and the phase transforms from the initial amorphous CoS x to form highly polycrystalline cobalt oxide/(oxy)hydroxide (Fig. 8c and d). After the OER process, the S 2p peak in the XPS spectra completely disappears, indicating the loss of all S from the surface (Fig. 8e). XANES demonstrates that the Co element is mainly in the Co3+ valence state, suggesting the transition from CoS x to Co3+ oxide/(oxy)hydroxide (Fig. 8f). In addition, this work also proves that CoOOH is the real active species. Taking the Ni-doped FeS2 reported by Cao et al. [163] as another example, the doping of Ni causes the electronic structure of FeS2 to shift from semiconductor to semimetal and provides subsequent topological transition, by which the Ni-FeS2-0.5 sample is completely transformed to amorphous Ni-doped FeOOH after the electrochemical oxidation reconstruction (Fig. 8g). As presented in the XANES tests spectra after the OER test, Fe exhibits an increase in the valence of the chemical compound (Fig. 8h) and Ni shifts to a higher energy level (approaching the + 2-oxidation state. Fig. 8i), indicating that the actual active state is Ni2+Fe3+OOH, which fully explains that the high valence oxidation state is the key factor for the high OER activity. Reconfiguration shifts the metals to higher valence sites, thereby endowing them with a unique electronic structure that promotes the OER properties. A detailed description and summary of the high-valent metal engineering strategy to enhance OER electrocatalytic performance is presented by Wang et al. [164]. In these cases, TMCs and TMPs are considered to be fully converted to oxides, and the enhanced OER activity is attributed to the increase of the electrochemical surface area/porosity/defects and the decrease of the grain size during electrochemical oxidation compared to normal metal oxides. For example, Wang et al. [165] fabricated Ni2P nanocrystals supported on graphene with a remarkably low overpotential of 285 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. However, after OER testing, the conversion of Ni2P to NiOOH has been demonstrated by XPS and TEM. Guan et al. [162] designed hollow Mo-CoP nanoarrays and found that their in-situ transformed Mo-CoOOH exhibits enhanced catalytic properties with a small Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1 and a low overpotential of 305 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Subsequently, Li et al. [166] constructed a core-branch CoP@NiFe-OH nanohybrid, which undergoes a structural transformation to CoOOH under alkaline OER conditions. These studies demonstrate that oxide materials are unstable under actual alkaline OER conditions and can be converted into oxyhydroxides or hydrated oxides, which exhibit superior catalytic properties after phase transition compared with those directly synthesized oxides. For instance, Xiong et al. [167] fabricated CC@FeP and CC@FeOOH. The FeP catalyst shows gradual surface oxidization, but the activity is significantly superior to that of FeOOH. Furthermore, Wang et al. [168] compared the activity of surface S residual NiFe (oxy) hydroxides derived from NiFe disulfides, which has an extremely low overpotential of 270 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Such bulk oxidation during OER has also been adopted as a new method to prepare superior electrocatalysts, especially in combination with elemental doping. Lin et al. [169] designed Mo-doped NiCoP nanosheet arrays as pre-catalysts. An electrochemical activation strategy for the formation of Mo-doped (Ni, Co) OOH from Mo-doped NiCoP was proposed to boost the electrocatalytic activity of OER and potentially improve the OER stability. Liu et al. [159] systematically investigated how the OER activity of TMPs varies with the catalyst composition. These studies indicate that there are many potential causes of the improvement of the catalytic performance. On the one hand, TMOs/TMOHs obtained by in-situ electrochemical oxidation can form nanostructures with high surface area, thus improving the overall performance, which is superior to the directly synthesized oxides/hydroxides. On the other hand, the conversion process may result in the formation of unusual amorphous or metastable metal oxide/hydroxides on the surface during the catalytic processes. Such a newly formed surface has higher catalytic activity and self-protection ability, making the converted catalyst more stable and efficient, which is difficult to be achieved by traditional synthesis methods. Amorphous NiFeP has good OER durability, which can survive at least 12 h under alkaline conditions. No Fe or Ni was found in the solution measured by inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), indicating that NiFeP is very stable in alkaline solutions. However, it should be noted that P may be present in solution species. P has lone pairs of electrons in the 3p orbitals, and transition metals have vacancies in the 3d orbitals that can accommodate electrons on the surface of P, thus increasing the local charge density. Therefore, it is considered that the formation of PO4 3– from P may produce more active states and accelerate the kinetic evolution of oxygen, while Fe and Ni couple to produce hydroxide. MOOH (M = Fe, Ni) is an effective product of the reaction and can further react with hydroxyl groups to produce oxygen [170]. We investigated the in-situ phase transition of TMPs with Ni2P as a representative, and CV activation was carried out before collecting the OER data. It was found that the characteristic peak of P completely disappears after activation by the XPS test, and the peak of Ni shifts to a higher energy level. In combination with HR-TEM and other tests, it is confirmed that Ni2P is converted to NiOOH within the detection line, which acts as the real active catalyst. The OER mechanism of pristine Ni2P, NiOOH formed from Ni2P and Cr-doped NiOOH was theoretically simulated to reveal the reaction mechanism, which is consistent with the experimental results [158]. In general, surface reconstructed catalysts refer to the catalysts with a surface oxide layer thickness of less than 10 nm and a limited degree of reconstruction. Since OER reactions generally occur near the surface [171], it is considered to be fully reconstructed if the oxide layer thickness is less than 10 nm [172]. It has also been reported that irreversible reconfiguration at high OER overpotentials is usually an undesired change in structure and composition. The reconstructions have been known to shorten the catalyst lifetime and can upset the balance between activity and stability, especially for TMCs and TMPs. Therefore, controlling the active species and improving the structural stability of TMCs and TMPs during the OER remain a great challenge. In summary, the reconstruction of TMPs and TMCs during OER has attracted extensive attention, and from a thermodynamic point of view, TMPs and TMCs are unstable under oxidation conditions in electrolyte. It is clear from the above-mentioned cases that the pre-catalysts can eventually be fully transformed unless there are structural or kinetic barriers, which are the main factors impeding the reconstruction process. The test conditions and environment of the reconstituted layer have a great influence on the degree of reconstruction, and thus, the degree of pre-catalyst reconstruction should be determined on a case-by-case basis. After the completion of reconstruction, it is clear that stability has been greatly improved. However, the mechanism is yet to be fully understood. For example, it is unclear to what degree of reconstruction has the greatest benefit for the catalytic activity, and it is also controversial whether to start from the pre-catalyst or the fully reconstructed substance when performing simulation calculations. However, from the perspective of thermodynamics, it is certain that TMPs and TMCs are likely to undergo reconstruction during the OER process. Researchers should focus on whether catalyst reconstruction occurs while investigating the catalytic performance in order to further identify the real active sites. Table 1 (Supplementary material) provides the electrochemical performance of several TMPs or TMCs. By comparison, the performance of most TMCS and TMPs is comparable to that of hydroxyl oxides, but the performance of TMCS and TMPs after reconstruction is slightly better than that of the original TMCs and TMPs. Therefore, this review article highlights that researchers should focus on whether catalyst reconstruction occurs while investigating the catalytic performance in order to further identify the real active sites and catalytic mechanism. 3.4 Investigation into the reconstruction process By characterizing the thickness of the reconstructed layer, it is possible to determine whether TMCs and TMPs are surface or bulk reconstructed. For pre-catalysts with changes in bulk morphology, or the presence or absence of specific elements, the thickness of the reconstructed layer can be easily determined by HRTEM or scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) combined with elemental mapping [173]. In addition, the presence or absence of elements in the pre-catalyst can be determined with the aid of characterization techniques such as XPS and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and XRD can be combined to determine if new material has formed. However, due to the short reconstitution time and variable reconstitution process, the surface self-reconstitution process of TMCs and TMPs in the catalytic OER process is difficult to be monitored and characterized using ex-situ characterization techniques, making it difficult to accurately capture the true active site of the catalytic OER and thus provide valuable information for understanding the OER reaction mechanism. In contrast, the use of in-situ/operando characterization techniques enables real-time characterization of pre-catalysts and can monitor the OER process by detecting reaction intermediates, thus further revealing the reconstructive behavior of TMCs and TMPs as well as the catalytic mechanism. The development of in situ technologies has made it possible to gain a clear understanding of the dynamic reconstructions of TMCs and TMPs under electrochemical test conditions, such as their electronic structure, chemical composition and morphology, as well as the in-situ adsorption/desorption processes of reaction intermediates. Currently, the common in situ/operando characterization techniques used to characterize pre-catalysts include in-situ/operando XAS, in-situ ambient-pressure XPS (AP-XPS), in-situ Raman spectroscopy, in-situ FT-IR, in-situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectroscopy and surface interrogation scanning electrochemical microscopy (SI-SECM), etc. XAS is a popular technique that provides information about the local atomic structure, chemical bonding, ligand environments and oxidation state of the material [174]. The generation of transition intermediates is determined by changes in metal valence and structure to determine if remodeling is occurring. Operating XAS (Fig. 9 a) has been used to monitor dynamic reconstruction processes to determine the oxidation state and the dynamics of the local coordination environment of Ir, Ni and Fe [175]. Chen et al. [160] developed a composite cobalt and iron nitride with a graded structure and introduced the concept of a “dynamic catalyst” to describe the electrochemical behavior of the metalloid in a zinc-air battery. The operando XAS technique reveals that the resulting “core-shell” configuration is the true state of the nitride during the operation of the Zn-air battery. The “core” is the nitride itself, while the “shell” is a composite hydroxyl oxide of cobalt and iron with an electrochemically responsive phase. XAS is a powerful tool to probe the electronic structure and chemical state information of pre-catalysts [87]. As shown in Fig. 9(b), in-situ AP-XPS enables real-time monitoring of the chemical composition and oxidation valence changes on the catalyst surface, allowing further insights into the true mechanism of OER by TMCs and TMPs [176]. Wang et al. [177] found by in-situ AP-XPS that cobalt phosphide nanoparticles underwent surface reconstruction under electrochemical conditions, with the presence of distinct Co–O peaks and the evolution of cobalt phosphide to hydroxide/oxide. Fig. 9(c) shows a schematic diagram of the in-situ Raman monitoring system, where the low frequency vibrational changes monitored in real time by in-situ Raman are combined with in situ XAS to reveal the active centers in the OER process [178]. Nam et al. [179] captured manganese oxide intermediates during electrochemical water oxidation at neutral by in-situ Raman spectroscopy. Zhang et al. [180] demonstrated by in-situ Raman that TMCs have converted to metal (oxygen) hydroxides in situ under OER conditions, revealing that they are efficient OER pre-catalysts. Therefore, if TMCs or TMPs evolve during the OER process, the intermediates can be detected by in-situ Raman spectroscopy and thus the evolution mechanism can be obtained. In-situ FT-IR is used to obtain absorption spectra by monitoring the vibration and rotation of molecules, which can be used for the qualitative analysis of TMCs and TMPs reconstitution intermediates and surface reconstitution products. The schematic diagram of an in-situ FT-IR device is shown in Fig. 9(d), when a sample is irradiated by infrared light with continuously varying frequency, the molecule would absorb radiation at some of these frequencies, vibrate or rotate, resulting in a net change in the dipole moment and a transition of the vibronic energy level from the ground state to the excited state [181]. Fan et al. [72] found that CoSx undergoes electrochemical conversion to oxides/hydroxides following OER by in-situ FT-IR. The in-depth observation of the structural evolution in OER measurements by this technique allows a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of OER catalysts. Fig. 9(e) shows a schematic diagram of the in-situ UV-vis absorption spectrum, based on electron conversion, which makes it easier to understand the redox processes of TMCs and TMPs in catalysis [182]. The reconstruction of TMCs and TMPs during the OER and their evolution can be determined by using in-situ UV-vis spectroscopy. Fig. 9(f) shows the schematic diagram of an SI-SECM setup, where SI-SECM can monitor the local electrochemical behavior of the liquid–solid interface of a reaction process to obtain the surface kinetic parameters of the reaction intermediates in order to identify the reactive sites [183]. In summary, the atomic/electronic structure of the active sites in TMCs and TMPs may change during the OER process. If these changes are irreversible, they may lead to phase/microstructure reconstruction at the macroscopic level. The phase/microstructure evolution of pre-catalysts can be characterized by a range of in situ characterization techniques. This will reveal the catalytic mechanism and reaction kinetics of TMCs and TMPs, this is an important direction for future development. 4 Typical strategies to promote the OER performance Limited by the slow reaction kinetics, OER is the bottleneck of electrocatalytic water splitting and aqueous metal-air batteries, which determines the overall Faraday efficiency of the electrolytic cell and the round-trip efficiency of the battery. Up to now, tremendous attempts have been made to design efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts. In the aforementioned chapter, we have introduced TMCs and TMPs that would undergo oxidization processes. From these but not limited to these studies, we summarize a list of strategies for designing TMCs and TMPs electrocatalysts. The main control strategies to enhance the performance of OER include morphology/structure control, chemical doping, compounding, defect strategies, etc. Modulation of pre-catalysts by these strategies can optimize the electronic structure and electron/mass transfer in the catalytic environment, thus improving their stability and catalytic activity [184,185]. 4.1 Morphology modulation Optimizing the size and morphology of electrocatalysts can maximize the exposure of active sites to enhance their OER catalytic activity. The synthesis and morphological engineering of TMCs and TMPs are of great significance because they provide abundant active sites for catalytic reactions [186,187]. Various morphological engineering strategies and growth mechanisms have been reported. However, correlation analyses are required for existing studies on complex nanostructures to gain insights into the development of the field. Key characteristics such as specific surface area, conductivity, crystallinity and energy gap that can be adjusted by morphology design and engineering should also be optimized to increase ECSA and promote OER performance. Typically, the extent to which a pre-catalyst is completely reconstructed during the OER process is related to the size of the pre-catalyst. The general surface reconstructed NiOOH layer is about 5 nm in depth. Mai et al. [188] successfully prepared a deeply reconstructed NiOOH (DR-NiOOH) catalyst by a single-cycle lithiation method, and achieved the complete reconstruction at sub-10 nm in depth. Those DR-NiOOH catalysts are composed of ultra-small nanoparticles that expose a large number of active sites, thus significantly enhancing the mass activity. The morphology of TMCs and TMPs reported so far mainly includes 1D nanowires, 2D nanosheets and 3D nanostructures. 1D materials, such as nanotubes (NTs) and nanowires (NWs), possess unique anisotropy advantages and generally exhibit better electrochemical activity compared with the corresponding nanoparticles. By calculating the binding energy of electrons via DFT, the obvious interfacial transfer effect is verified [189]. In particular, 1D nanomaterials have fewer lattice boundaries and controllable surface defect sites to facilitate mass transfer. With the development of nanotechnology, anisotropic metal-based 1D nanostructures have been successfully synthesized, which exhibit an enhanced activity. For instance, Xia et al. [108] found that, compared with pure Co0.85Se, the uniquely structured (Ni, Co)0.85Se nanotube has excellent corrosion resistance, high electrical conductivity and great OER activity, which can be used as an advanced OER catalyst or skeleton material. As an emerging new nanomaterial, the ultrathin 2D nanosheets have a high specific surface area, which not only facilitate the exposure of active sites, but also provide rich absorption sites for active substances in electrocatalysis, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. Moreover, the strong in-plane and out-of-plane coupling between atoms in 2D nanostructures has unique electrochemical properties. For example, Zhou et al. [131] reported a transverse heterostructured MoS2-WS2 nanostructure by morphologic engineering. Such 2D nanosheets have great potential for applications due to their unique properties. Understanding the quantum confinement effects of these two-dimensional materials is essential for quantum applications. Efforts have been devoted to the preparation of novel structures of TMCs and TMPs with quantum effects to enhance the electrochemical properties through strong electronic interactions. The 3D TMCs and TMPs with mesoporous structures and hollow structures are beneficial to the exposure of active sites, the adsorption of intermediate media, and mass transfer. Increasing the contact area between the electrolyte and the catalyst, decreasing the electron transfer resistance and increasing the active sites will greatly improve the reaction efficiency. Consequently, morphological engineering is effective in precisely tuning the OER performance of TMCs and TMPs. 4.2 Crystal structure engineering 4.2.1 Crystal engineering The stacking pattern of metal atoms in different crystal structures directly determines the very different electronic structures of the metallic materials themselves. Different crystal structures cause lattice strains such as stretching and compression, which affect the adsorption energy of sites to intermediates, and this has a crucial impact on their non-homogeneous catalytic properties. The high-index facet contains high density step atoms and kink atoms, and its coordination number is very low. Such a facet can easily interact with the reaction molecule and becomes the catalytic active center, thus greatly improving the catalytic activity and stability compared with that of the low-index plane. Because the surface energy of the high-index plane is very high, according to the crystal growth law, the crystal growth speed along the direction of the high-index plane is much faster than that along the direction of the low-index facets, resulting in the disappearance of the high-index crystal plane. Therefore, the synthesis of materials with high-index crystal planes is very challenging [190,191]. Different crystal structures and crystal surfaces often have different chemical catalytic properties. In general, the surface exposure of high-index facets has a higher atomic step, which can be used as highly active reaction sites. Therefore, fine adjustment of crystal surface structures at the atomic level and exposure of high-index facet surfaces are potential ways to obtain highly active catalysts. For instance, Feng et al. [117] achieved in-situ growth of 2 ¯ 10 high-index faceted Ni3S2 on nickel foam, which can serve as a highly active catalyst with a low overpotential (η = 260 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2). More significantly, the combination of experiments and DFT calculations proves that the outstanding performance of Ni3S2/NF is mainly due to the exposure of 2 ¯ 10 high-index facets. Later, Deng et al. [192] constructed core-branch array structured TiO2@Ni3S2 with a lower overpotential (220 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2) for OER. It confirms that the exposure of the high-index facet 2 ¯ 10 in the Ni3S2 nanosheet mainly contributes to the excellent performance. 4.2.2 Defect engineering Defect engineering has been widely recognized as an effective method to modulate the electronic structure of interfaces, which can be used to reasonably design the electrocatalyst with defect structures in order to optimize the electrocatalytic activity. If there are defects in nanomaterials, unsaturated sites can be well introduced into the coordination process as highly active sites for activation and molecular chemisorption. According to the location of the defects, they can be divided into surface defects and body defects. Surface defects can be divided into point defects, line defects and plane defects. Defects are widely used to regulate the electronic structure and interfacial electrochemical properties, because they not only effectively promote charge transfer and ion diffusion, but also provide more active sites for guest ions and intermediates. For example, it was found [193] by EIS and CV tests that oxygen-rich vacancies (Vo) can balance the charge, promote the pre-oxidation of low-valent Co (Co2+), optimize the adsorption and deprotonation of Co-OOH•, and thus substantially enhance the OER performance. Liu et al. [37] constructed CoSe2 from the atomic scale and detected a large number of Co defects (VCo″) through X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS). DFT calculations revealed that these VCo″ vacancies can serve as active sites to boost the OER performance, presenting a 320 mV overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Similarly, Dou et al. [194] synthesized nanometer-thick CoSe2-DFe-VCo nanoribbons for OER. The combination of experiments and DFT calculations proved that Co vacancies and Fe doping work synergistically to optimize the electronic state of Co2 with the highest active center, which significantly reduces the intermediate OH* binding energy and dramatically increases the catalytic activity (Fig. 10 ). It can be concluded that by Fe doping and Co vacancy, nearly optimal intermediate binding energy can be achieved (Fig. 10h). Defects can change the energy level and increase the electrical conductivity. At the same time, it helps to increase the reactivity and the number of active sites on the surface. In some cases, abundant oxygen vacancies lead to local deformation of the metal–O bond, which reduces electron transfer between the catalyst surface and the OER intermediate and thus enhances the OER electrochemical performance [195]. During the OER electrochemical process, the electrocatalyst surface sites are dynamically stabilized to trigger the occurrence of remodeling. Reconfiguration may lead to changes in the crystal structure, which are related to the active sites participating in the reaction after the structural conversion. The catalytic behavior of adsorption, activation, and desorption is regulated by the reconstruction, which in turn affects the OER performance. The ion leaching effect leaves vacant sites, which changes the crystal structure and adjusts the adsorption of hydroxide ions by the pre-catalyst, thus optimizing the OER activity [196]. The dissolution of metal ions can also induce the emergence of new crystal structures and d-band vacancies to form oxygen ligands with high electrophilic properties, thereby forming oxygen–oxygen bonds, reducing the kinetic energy barrier, and enhancing the OER catalytic activity [197]. Therefore, the crystal structure induced by vacancies is significant for optimizing the OER performance, as described in detail in our previous review [198]. For the TMP and TMC crystal structures, future work is required to systematically investigate the structural transition between the reconstructed layer and the pre-catalyst and the mechanism of the reconstruction. In addition, the original structure of the designed pre-catalyst needs to be considered. 4.3 Stress engineering Strain engineering introduces mechanics, a traditional field concept, to electrochemistry. Strain introduction, including both intrinsic and artificial strain, is the basis for the study of strain effects. Electronic structures modified with strain effects have a close connection to catalytic reactions, and it has been revealed that catalysts with strain effects have better electrocatalytic performance compared with those without strain effects [199].
