Strain usually exists in conjunction with ligand effect, which can modify the electronic structure and surface adsorption strength of the material, thus effectively regulating the OER activity of the material. Currently, intrinsic strain is usually applied to materials by using lattice mismatches between epitaxial films and substrates [200]. The strategies employed for artificial strain can be broadly classified into mechanical and chemical methods. The mechanical method is to introduce strain by applying an external force to a material, while the chemical method is to introduce strain by changing the local lattice structure via doping, alloying, heterostructuring, phase engineering and so on [7,69,201–206]. The use of strain engineering to modulate the electronic structure of TMPs or TMCs for OER applications is relatively rare. 2D materials of TMCs are mainly used for HER or photocatalytic direction [199,207–209]. However, related reports have confirmed that strain engineering can optimize catalytic activity by modulating the properties of electronic structure, lattice vibrations, and electronic, optical and thermal conductivity, and thus reveal the strain-activity relationship of catalyst materials [210,211]. The synergistic effect of strain effect and ligand effect is helpful to the optimization of electrocatalytic activity and stability. Strain effect results in the transfer of the d-band center and changes the binding energy of adsorption. As illustrated in Fig. 11 (a), for early transition metals with d-bands smaller than half-filled, using the same parametric line, tensile strain or lower alignment has opposite effects on the d-band center. Specifically, the narrowing of the energy band caused by tensile strain or lower alignment leads to a downward shift of the d-energy band center, which weakens the interaction with the adsorbed state. To explore the strain effect of d-band center displacement, the effects of different transverse lattice constants (without strain, 1% and 2% expansion, 1.5% and 3% compression) have been systematically investigated. The results show that the d-band centers of the surface atoms such as Mn (111) and Cr (110) are shifted downward during lattice strain-driven expansion, while the d-band centers of the surface atoms of Mn (111) and Cr (110) are below their respective Fermi energies, reflecting a typical trend for transition metals. Unexpectedly, the d-band center of Zr (001) is not affected by lattice strain (Fig. 11b) [212]. The direct influence of electronic structure on catalytic performance is revealed. TOF is often used to evaluate the true electrocatalytic ability of a material, as shown in Fig. 11(c). It is clear that the 1 T phase has better activity than bulk WS2 and annealed WS2 (300 °C) because the 1 T phase has high conductivity and distortion. As the temperature increases, the 1 T phase reduces, and the performance worsens [213]. Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity can be improved, and the electronic structure of the material can be optimized by stress regulation. Lattice strains, including tensile and compressive stresses, can be changed by varying the distance between different atoms on the material surface or electron structure [7,214,215]. Taking lattice-strained metal framework compounds (MOF) as an example, the stretching lattice strain shifts the O 2p band upward and promotes electron exchange in the Ni 3d orbital, resulting in greater covalency of the Ni–O bond. As a result, the surface oxygen-containing species are thermodynamically inclined to bond with the neighboring Ni atoms to enhance the high oxygen-containing catalytic activity (Fig. 11d) [216]. Numerous studies have shown that the most commonly used stress regulation method is to fabricate core–shell structures and metal vacancies in nanocrystals to form lattice mismatches. Currently, the reported methods are mainly limited to compression strain and unstable charge transfer, such as larger Pt lattice, which provides a new direction for the stress electronic structure regulation of other catalysts [217]. For instance, Putungan et al. [218] used DFT to calculate the effect of strain in 1 T'-MoS2 monolayer on catalysis. The results showed that when the strain reaches 10%, the binding energy increases significantly which promotes the charge transfer in the catalytic process, while the higher vacancy concentration leads to surface instability. If S vacancies and strain exist simultaneously, and both the vacancy concentration and strain are large, it will not be conducive to the catalytic reaction. The nature of the S-vacancy activity is further revealed by the study of its electronic structure. When 25% S vacancy is introduced, new energy bands appear for the vacancies near the Fermi energy level (Fig. 11f, middle, red curve). These new gap states represent adsorption on the S vacancies, and the energy bands move toward the Fermi energy level as the S vacancies increase. When strain is applied, the positions of these new bands move further towards the Fermi energy level, leading to a further narrowing of the band gap and an increase in the number of gap states around the Fermi energy level, which also increases the strength of adsorption on the S-vacancy sites (Fig. 11f, right). Thus, creating the right amount of vacancies and strains can optimize the catalytic activity in the electronic structure of materials [219]. Therefore, the electronic structure of TMCs and TMPs can be tuned from the perspective of lattice strain to improve the performance. However, studies in this area are lacking, and many gaps need to be filled. The catalytic effect is often influenced by a combination of stress and electronic effects. Elastic strain can alter the lattice spacing and atomic structure of the alloy catalyst surface, thereby modulating the surface chemistry, reaction pathways and catalytic activity of the catalyst. In general, elastic strain applied to metal surfaces can be divided into active and passive forms. Passive strain, such as the construction of the shell-core structure of an alloy, is largely dependent on the lattice dislocation of the shell-core material, however this strain is fixed and cannot be adjusted. Active strain (which can also be called mechanical force) has none of these disadvantages and can be used directly to study the effect of strain on catalytic activity. 4.4 Element doping Element doping is a versatile strategy to improve the intrinsic activity of catalysts. By doping, the electronic structure of nanomaterials can be tuned so that the catalysts gain specific physicochemical properties [220]. In addition, the optimal conditions of doping can be accurately predicted from the atomic scale by theoretical calculations. In recent years, tremendous attempts have been made on the doping of TMCs and TMPs, mainly including cationic doping, anion doping and mixed doping. Wu et al. [93] designed Cr-doped FeNi-P/NCN with an overpotential of 240 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH solution. As shown in Fig. 12 (a–c), theoretical calculations demonstrate that Cr doping can effectively change the relative Gibbs adsorption energy and reduce the theoretical overpotential. Moreover, as mentioned above, for TMCs and TMPs in OER, many studies indicate that their true catalytic active sites come from as-formed surface hydroxides. Therefore, the cationic regulation strategy regulates the electronic structure derived from hydroxides. For instance, as shown in Fig. 12(f), Guan et al. [162] synthesized Mo-doped CoOOH which exhibits an excellent activity towards the OER with a low Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1 and requires an overpotential of only 305 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2. In addition, the influence of Mo doping on the adsorption free energy of intermediates has been further investigated by DFT calculations. Similarly, Liu et al. [221] developed V-doped NiS2 nanosheets by engineering V to Ni sites with an overpotential of about 290 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 12g and h), which is confirmed by XAS measurements and DFT calculations. This work provides the potential to improve the electrochemical performance from the engineering of electronic structures and well-designed atom-doped TMCs. The preparation of TMC and TMP catalysts by ion doping is undoubtedly the development direction to improve their performance in the future. Xu et al. [222] prepared Fe–Co bimetallic nanocomplexes derived from P-doped MOF, which exhibit high catalytic performance comparable to that of commercial RuO2. The improved OER performance through heteroatom doping is mainly attributed to the increased high specific surface area and electrical conductivity [223]. Thus, elemental doping not only modulates the electronic structure of the catalyst, but also optimizes the adsorption–desorption capacity of the catalyst for reactants, intermediates or products, thus contributing to the improvement of the OER performance of the catalyst. 4.5 Coupling with carbon Carbon materials have the advantages of high specific surface area, good electrical conductivity, outstanding inherent and structural flexibility, light-weight, high chemical inertness and thermal stability, easy chemical functionalization and mass production, etc., making them ideal candidates for catalytic carriers [224]. Accordingly, nano-carbon transition metal compounds have been demonstrated to deliver excellent properties owing to their tunable sizes, electronic structures, metallic conductivity, and high electrical conductivity of carbon carriers. Liu et al. [225] reported the synthesis of echinopluteus-like Co-based MOF (EC-MOF) by a general vapor-phase method, and then the preparation of Co3S4/EC-MOF by a vulcanization approach, which has excellent performance for OER, requiring an overpotential of only 226 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2. The experiments combined with DFT calculations revealed that the electron transfer between Co3S4 and EC-MOF reduces the electron density of the d-orbital of Co, thereby greatly optimizing the electro-catalytic adsorption performance of Co. Zahran et al. [226] covered a layer of C3N4 with a thickness of about 20–30 nm on NiS x by a simple method (Fig. 13 a). Under galvanostatic conditions at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 after 5 h, the XPS characteristic peak of S disappears and the characteristic peak of Ni shifts to a high energy level (Fig. 13b and c), demonstrating that a reconfiguration has occurred, and NiS x is converted to NiOOH. Chronopotentiogram test results showed that the stability of NiS x /C3N4 is better than that of NiS (Fig. 13d), suggesting that the C3N4 layer plays a positive role, and the generated NiOOH by activation exhibits an overpotential as low as 32 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13e). Mai et al. [165] prepared a MOF derived carbon-constrained Ni2P nanocrystal and then loaded on graphene to form a Ni2P@C/G structure with high specific surface area and strong charge transport capacity, which exhibits an overpotential of 285 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13f). The peak of P disappears and cannot be detected by XPS (Fig. 13g), indicating that the active substance is NiOOH. In addition, TMCs and TMPs can be hybridized with the hottest MXene of today to form composites. Although pure MXenes are not efficient OER catalysts, they can act as conductive carriers to modulate the electronic structure and density of their coupled OER co-catalysts, increase the energy level of the d-band centers (Fig. 13h), and even generate additional OER active sites to greatly enhance the OER activity. As an example, NiFeP/MXene exhibits a low overpotential of 286 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and the Tafel slope of 35 mV dec−1. Experimental and DFT results show that this is mainly due to the combination of MXene and phosphating in modulating the energy level of the d-band center, which can effectively optimize the electron density and enhance the stability [227]. Therefore, it is expected that TMC and TMP precatalysts with nano-carbon materials can further improve the OER performance. 5 Summary and perspectives In this review, we have systematically reviewed the basic knowledge of TMCs and TMPs as OER pre-catalysts, the progress of surface reconstruction, the reconstruction techniques in OER catalysis, the basic understanding of reconstruction materials and the improvement strategies for designing efficient OER pre-catalysts. In short, TMCs and TMPs as effective OER pre-catalysts are discussed and studied. First, we have summarized the role of TMPs and TMCs as true catalysts, followed by their in-situ conversion to corresponding TMO/TMOHs under basic OER conditions. Some of the changes occur at the surface, and complete conversion occurs in the bulk phase. Various strategies for developing TMCs and TMPs as OER pre-catalysts are subsequently reviewed. Generally, these pre-catalysts exhibit significant electrochemical properties, which are superior to those directly synthesized oxides/(oxy)hydroxides. This may be due to the good conductivity of TMCs and TMPs as conducting scaffolds for metal oxide/(oxy)hydroxide active sites, or the electronic synergy between different components or composite metals. Furthermore, TMCs and TMPs can be used as precursors for the preparation of oxide/(oxy)hydroxide OER catalysts on the surface of the original nano-catalysts to form nanostructured composites with high specific surface areas, which is of great significance for improving the electro-catalytic performance of OER. Through a series of studies, it is necessary to understand the morphology and composition changes of the synthesized samples after electrochemical action. OER is a complex reaction with slow kinetics. TMCs and TMPs nanomaterials are used to catalyze OER due to their unique advantages. However, the development of low-cost and highly active OER catalysts remains a great challenge. Although it has been reported that TMCs and TMPs undergo reconstruction and function as pre-catalysts instead of direct catalysts, the design and in-depth understanding of reconstruction chemistry, reconstruction electrochemistry, and controlled reconstruction engineering need to be further explored. Furthermore, to understand the catalytic processes of these nanomaterials, many other factors need to be further studied, including but not limited to the following aspects: (i) Improving intrinsic activity. The mechanism of OER can be studied by DFT calculations, and novel catalysts can be designed by understanding the scaling between the intermediates HOO* and HO*. For example, both HO* and HOO* can be independently stabilized in the reaction system, and the introduction of proton receptors can regulate the adsorption energy of intermediate products from the intrinsic activity of TMCs and TMPs. and optimize the energy barrier at each step of the OER reaction, aiming to approach the OER potential of 1.23 V. By this way, the interrelationship among the adsorbed intermediate and transition states and the products can be determined during OER electrocatalysis. (ii) Making the most of surface reorganization. The effect of reconstitution on the catalytic systems should be carefully examined; the reconstitution is not necessarily beneficial to the catalytic activity. For example, the formation of M−O species can be induced on the surface of the catalyst by doping to form vacancies, allowing the electronic states to be redistributed and thus optimizing the adsorption of OH* and OOH* intermediates. Surface reorganization is facilitated by several methods that allow some non-OER active catalysts to have the OER activity. In addition, a proper understanding of the phenomenon of catalyst recombination goes beyond assessing the stability of the catalyst in terms of performance stability. (iii) Development of TMCs and TMPs in addition to the iron triad. As summarized above, the main group VIII is still being synthesized, and thus more TMC and TMP nanomaterials of other groups can be explored. Alternatively, a combination of catalyst design strategies such as defect, doping, recombination, phase engineering and strain engineering could be used for the design of electrocatalytic materials. (iv) Advanced techniques for in-situ observation. Since TMCs and TMPs are highly active OER pre-catalysts, their morphology or structure undergoes changes in the alkaline OER process, such as surface oxidation to form core–shell structures and completely oxidation. In general, these changes are investigated via ex-situ characterization after the reaction in previous studies, in which the changes and the adsorption behavior of such pre-catalysts on intermediates are difficult to visualize in real time. Therefore, the proposed OER mechanism and the direct experimental evidence for determining the real active sites are still limited. There is an urgent need to develop in-situ experimental approaches or/and operando spectroscopic characterization technologies that can visually detect the process of reaction changes to obtain information that is previously difficult to capture. Thus, we can infer the evolution mechanism of TMCs and TMPs. (v) Reconstruction mechanism of electrocatalysts. Since TMCs and TMPs are pre-catalysts under alkaline OER conditions, the mechanism of action between these nanomaterials and intermediates is worth investigating. Experiments and theoretical calculations should be conducted to investigate whether there is a change, how it is changed, the mechanism of action after the change, and whether the structure is reconstructed in the non-OER reaction area. The relationship between the degree of change and surface chemistry should be discussed through theoretical calculations, so as to form a systematic theory to explain the reconstruction process of pre-catalysts and to further predict the transformation in the OER process. Furthermore, the evolution of catalysts in electrocatalysis and the factors that affect the degree of evolution, such as synthesis method, synthesis conditions, pH value, reaction temperature, voltage, time, etc., have not been systematically studied, which is very important for the development of catalysts with high selectivity, high activity and long-term stability. It is suggested to optimize the reaction parameters, use machine learning to simulate the whole reaction process and predict the dynamic evolution, deduce the reconstruction mechanism from the theoretical calculation, and then verify it in conjunction with experiments. Future research through a combination of machine learning and in situ test experiments is an important topic, which is expected to greatly improve research efficiency. (vi) Accurate computational simulations to study real electrocatalytic reaction mechanism of action. Although a series of characterizations and DFT calculations have been successfully employed in OER catalysis, there are still some limitations. DFT calculation can simulate the action mechanism of pre-catalysts. By comparing with experimental results, it can be concluded whether reconstruction has occurred. However, to reveal the catalytic mechanism of action, the reconstructed physical phase, crystal plane and structure should be considered, and we should not simply choose the pre-catalyst as the calculation model. In addition, since current in-situ electrochemical structures and the corresponding experimental equipment cannot provide sufficient accuracy, and the depth of acquisition may not be sufficient, the accuracy of DFT calculations can be affected. Furthermore, depending on the choice of model structures (exposed surface) and simulation parameters (exchange correlation function and U value), the calculated results may vary greatly. Therefore, further development of advanced in situ techniques to accurately capture real-world dynamically reconstructed electrocatalysts and rational construction of theoretical models are highly needed in the future. (vii) Determination of true OER-active species. The controversy over the active sites of TMCs and TMPs has highlighted the difficulty in accurately detecting the true active sites of heterogeneous catalysts, even after a series of advanced experiments and DFT calculations. Identification of real active sites is crucial to the next step of reasonable design and improvement of catalysts. (viii) If TMCs and TMPs are pre-catalysts in alkaline OER, what is the role of heteroatom N/P/S in this process? In-depth theoretical insights are urgently needed on whether phosphorus and sulfur, among others, play a role in OER activity enhancement. In summary, electrochemical oxidation based on TMCs and TMPs has developed extremely rapidly in recent years, but in-depth understanding of OER pre-catalysts is still in its infancy. It is necessary to further study the nature and the changing process of these nanomaterials. We should spare no effort to continue our study and expect more critical advances and breakthroughs in this area of research in the near future. Bull., 66 (2021) 1063-1072. Xiaolin Hu entered in the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Chongqing University as a Master student in 2016. She received Ph.D. degree in the College of Aerospace Engineering Chongqing University with Prof. Chaohe Xu in 2021. She is now conducting postdoctoral research with Prof. Zidong Wei in the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University. She is a lecturer at the School of Science in Chongqing University of Technology. Her current research focuses on the development of functional materials and their applications in secondary batteries and electrocatalysis. Ronghua Wang received her Ph.D. degree from Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2014. She is now an associate professor at School of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University. She has published over 50 papers in peer-reviewed journals and filled 10 patents in materials for batteries. Her current research area includes lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors and aqueous metal-ion batteries. Wenlin Feng is currently a professor of School of Science in CQUT, China. He got his Ph.D. degree from Sichuan University in 2008. He was an Optical Engineering postdoctoral Fellow at Chongqing University from 2009-2011. He was also associated as a Visiting Scientist at Tsinghua University in 2011, University of Arkansas at Little Rock, USA during 2014-2015. His research interests are synthesis, modification and application of nanomaterials, such as graphene, sensing membrane, MOFs, etc., and their applications in sensors, energy storage, luminescence, etc. He has published more than 180 research articles in reputed international journals and holds 20 Chinese patents. Chaohe Xu is a professor at the College of Aerospace Engineering and National Engineering Research Center for Magnesium Alloys in Chongqing University. He received BS degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Tianjin University in 2007, and Ph.D. degree in Materials Physics and Chemistry from Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2012. In 2013–2015, he worked as a postdoctoral research fellow at Department of Chemical and Molecular Biological Engineering, National University of Singapore. Then, he moved to Chongqing University as an assistant professor in 2015–2021. He has published over 110 papers in peer-reviewed journals and filled 14 patents in materials for batteries. His current research interests include rechargeable lithium/sodium/magnesium batteries, all-solid-state batteries and their interface engineering, electrocatalysts and supercapacitors. Zidong Wei received his Ph.D. from the Tianjin University in 1994. Currently, he is a full professor in Chongqing University. His research interests include electrocatalysis, computational study, electrochemical materials and their applications in catalysis and energy storage. He has published over 300 papers in peer-reviewed journals. His works have been cited over 20000 times. He has been granted 43 patents associated with catalysis. He has served as an Editorial Board Member of 7 International and China based journals.

coredata.dc:description: The development of inexpensive and efficient electrocatalysts is key to commercializing energy-related electrocatalytic techniques such as water electrolyzers and metal-air batteries. In particular, novel oxygen evolution reaction (OER) pre-catalysts, such as transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) and phosphides (TMPs), have evolved in recent years from traditional stable OER electrocatalysts, which show superior OER electrocatalytic performance compared with transition metal oxides (TMOs) or (oxy)hydroxides (TMOHs). In this feature article, we summarize recent advances in the development of TMC- and TMP-based OER electrocatalysts, as well as approaches to improve the OER performance in terms of morphology, structure, composition, surface engineering, lattice-strained and in-situ transformation in the electrolysis process. In particular, the electrochemical stability of TMCs and TMPs in alkaline electrolytes and the evolution of morphology, structure and composition under OER conditions are discussed. In the last section, we discuss the challenges that need to be addressed in this specific area of research and the implications for further research.
